thread.title: Tasmania could be in for cicada plague in next few years
thread.title_full: Tasmania could be in for cicada plague in next few years

title: Tasmania could be in for cicada plague in next few years
text:
As the sun warms the morning air in a bushland reserve in northern Tasmania, a chorus of red eye cicadas comes alive and hits in waves of sound. 
Cicada numbers are expected to increase in the next few years after a wet winter in 2016. 
Simon Fearn is the collections officer at the Queen Victoria Museum and Art Gallery, specialising in bugs and reptiles, and he thinks in the next few years the number of cicadas in northern Tasmania could be huge. 
"This year we've quite cool temperatures and a lot of rain so it should be really good conditions for the little nymphs to survive," Mr Fearn said. 
"In two or three years time keep a look out, there could be a plague." 
Almost right on cue, the sound of cicadas overtakes all other sounds in the bush, and Mr Fearn excitedly explains more about the small insect. 
"As it warms up, more and more start and then you get this low hum as they all start up their engines, and then one will do the proper call," he said. Photo: Cicadas are quite vulnerable after hatching from the nymph shell. (ABC Northern Tasmania: Fred Hooper) 
The majority of tree trunks are covered in ghost-like shells of young cicadas that have emerged from the ground to hatch. 
The shells are actually the remains of the larval stage that lives underground, sucking nutrients from tree roots, and can remain there for long periods of time. 
"They spend two or three years underground as a larvae, and then on a warm summer's evening, usually around the middle of December, they'll all emerge out of the ground in huge numbers," Mr Fearn said. 
"When it [the cicada] first comes out it's all soft and white and the wings are tiny little buds. It then has to pump blood into its wings and expand them out." 
It can take several hours for the cicada wings to harden before the insect takes flight and searches for a mate. 
Even though the red eye cicada found in Tasmania hatches annually, the number can fluctuate depending on the conditions a few years earlier. Photo: The cicadas will live in the ground for two to three years in this state. (ABC Northern Tasmania: Fred Hooper) 
"From year to year the numbers vary widely, so some years there are millions and millions of them and other years they're quite scarce," Mr Fearn said. 
As Mr Fearn walks through the bushland reserve, he points out a number of adult cicadas that have not been able to make it from the lower section of the tree trunks. 
"If you walk around the bush now, you'll see quite a few adults that are fairly sick, they're fairy slow, they're fairly sluggish," he said. 
"They haven't got the energy to get up high anymore." Photo: The 2016 Tasmanian winter provided good conditions for cicada-breeding over summer. (ABC Northern Tasmania: Fred Hooper) 
Mr Fearn said the best indicator of future numbers was the weather conditions about two years before hatching. 
With cicada numbers strong this year, Mr Fearn has predicted an even larger season in a few years after a wet 2016 winter. 
"If the ground is baked rock hard and it's super hot, they [the nymph cidadas] probably don't survive as well as ones that hatch in a good season like this season," Mr Fearn said. 
"I would expect in two or three years time that there will be a mass emergence."
